entry.title: Biological Physics
entry.content:
Intro-Biomolecules

Statistical-Physics-Basics

Basics

Microstate: M particles, N levels: \(\Omega = M^N\) Macrostate:Histogram of the number of particles per energy level Macrostate{3, 1,5}:

  • 3 particles are in level 1
  • 1 particle is in level 2
  • 5 particles are in level 3

Fundamental concept of statistical Physics

  • Describe a system only as a MACROSTATE = Histogram
  • It is not relevant which individual particle is in what level
  • Compared to the exact description of a system (MICROSTATE),information is lost. A histogram contains LESS information than the dataset that generated it
  • Cannot construct the exact(MICROSTATE) of a system from theMACROSTATE because the MACROSTATE is just a distribution
  • The amount of the missing information is measureed by thestatistical weight \(\Omega\) of theMacrostate, or \(\ln(\Omega)\)

Stastical weight of a macrostate \(\Omega\)

How many microstates belong to the macrostate eg: {2,0,0,1,0} has 3microstates

\(\Omega =N!\)(æ‰€æœ‰ç²’å­èƒ½é‡å‡ä¸ç›¸åŒ)

Degeneracy

\({1,0,0,2}: \Omega = rac{3!}{2!}\)

Entropy

\(S = k_B \ln \Omega, \Omega = rac{N!}{n_0!n_1!\cdots}\)

Stirling's theorem \[N!\approx rac{N^N}{e^N}\sqrt{2\pi N}\] \[\ln N! \approx N \ln N -N\]

Entropy S is a property of a macrostate of a system, gives the levelof disorder of that macrostate

Boltzman-Free-Energy

Boltzman

\(\ln \Omega = \ln rac{N!}{\prod_{i}n_i!}= N\ln N - \sum_{i}(n_i\ln n_i)\) Maximum of entropy occurs for\(dS = d(k_B \ln \Omega)=0\) \[d\ln\Omega=-\sum_{i}\ln n_i dn_i=0\] \(\sum_i n_i = N, \sum_i dn_i=0\) UseLagrange's method of undertimined multipliers: \(n_i = rac{N}{M}\)

Microcanonical ensemble

\[\sum_i \epsilon_in_i = E\] \(n_i = Ae^{- eta\epsilon_i},A =e^{-\lambda}\) \(n_i =N rac{e^{- eta\epsilon_i}}{\sum_ie^{- eta\epsilon_i}}\) \(p_i = rac{e^{- eta\epsilon_i}}{\sum_ie^{- eta\epsilon_i}}\) \(Z = \sum_{i=1}^{M}e^{- eta\epsilon_i}\)\(T=0, eta = \infty,p_1=1,p_{i\geq2}=0\) \(T=\infty, eta=0,p_i = rac{1}{M}\) \(E = \sum_i\epsilon_in_i=N\sum_i\epsilon_ip_i= rac{N}{Z}\sum_i\epsilon_ie^{- eta\epsilon_i}=-N rac{\partial\lnZ}{\partial eta}\)

Constant total energy of system depends on temperature

Connection

\(dQ=TdS\) \[E=U=\sum_i\epsilon_in_i\] \[dU =\sum_i\epsilon_idn_i+\sum_in_id\epsilon_i\] å› ä¸º\(\ln \Omega\)é‡Œé¢æœ‰\(dn_i\)ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ç¬¬ä¸€é¡¹æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯\(dQ\)ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒé¡¹æ˜¯\(dW\)

Ensembles

\[S_{AB}=S_A+S_B\]

çœ‹çœ‹ä¸‹é¢ä¸‰ä¸ªå®šä¹‰æ€ä¹ˆæ¨çš„

Temperature definition

\[ rac{1}{T}\equiv rac{\partialS}{\partial E}\]

Pressure definition

\[ rac{P}{T}=( rac{\partial S}{\partialV})_E\]

Chemical potentialdefinition

\[ rac{\mu}{T}=-( rac{\partialS}{\partial N})_{E,V}\]

Free energy

çœ‹pptè¿˜æœ‰tutorialå§

Partition Function

Degeneracy

\(Z=e^{- eta\epsilon_1}+2e^{- eta\epsilon_2}\)

In equilibrium, E,S and F are connected t Z bysimple equations

\(S= rac{E}{T}+Nk\ln Z\) \(F =E-TS\) \(S=Nk(\ln Z +T rac{\ln Z}{\partialT})\)

Partition function of thesystem

\(Z_N=Z^N\) \(Z_N=\sum_ie^{- eta E_i}\)

BoltzmannDistribution derivation by system

\(p_i= rac{1}{Z_N}e^{- eta\epsilon_i}\)

Mixing-Osmosis

Mixing Entropy and dilutesolutions

Lattice models: \(N=N_W+N_S\)

Entropy of Mixing

Polymer solutions-Mixingentropy

Polymer solutions

Entropy of mixing: \(\Delta S_{mix}=-k(A\ln rac{A}{A+B}+B\ln rac{B}{A+B})\)

çœ‹pptè¿˜æœ‰tutorialå§

Osmosis

Entropy of mixing: \(\DeltaS_{mix}=-k(N_S\ln rac{N_S}{N_S+N_W}+N_W\ln rac{N_W}{N_S+N_W})\approx-k(N_S\ln rac{N_S}{N_W}-N_S)\)

Solvation energy = contribution per solute molecule multiplied by thetotal number of such molecules. \[dU=\epsilon_s dn_s\] First law ofthermodynamics \(\epsilon_sdN_s+\mu_W^0dN_W=TdS+\mu_SdN_S+\mu_WdN_W\)åˆ†åˆ«ä»¤\(dN_S,dN_W=0\), æœ‰\(\mu_W=\dots, \mu_S = \dots\) ä½¿ç”¨\(\Delta S_{mix}\)å¾—åˆ°æ‰€éœ€åå¯¼æœ€åå¾—åˆ°ï¼š\(\mu_S=\epsilon_S+kT\ln rac{n_S}{n_W}\) \[\mu_S=\mu_0+kT\ln rac{c}{c_0},\enspace c = rac{n_S}{V},\enspacec_0= rac{n_W}{V}\]

Osmotic Pressure

\[\Delta P=cRT\] \(R = k_BN_A\) if equation contains kB,quantities relate to one particle, otherwise relate to one mole

\[\Delta P=cRT,\enspacec(mol/L)\]

\[\Delta P=ck_BT,\enspacec(ä¸ª/m^3)\]

Revere Osmosis

çœ‹tutorialå§

5. Binding

5.1 Equilibria Binding

Ligand-Receptor Binding

è¦çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹pptå’Œtutorialï¼Œæ¨\(p_{bound}\) Hill function

Reactions

\[K_{eq} \equiv \prod_ic_{i-eq}^{\upsilon_i}\]

\(\Delta G = \sum_i\upsilon_i\mu_i\)\(\mu = \mu_0+kT\ln rac{c}{c_0}\)\(\Delta G =0\) \[\Delta G_0=-k_BT\ln K_{eq}\]

\[\Delta G=k_BT\ln rac{K}{K_{eq}}\]

5.2 Protein folding

å…¨æ˜¯å™è¿°ï¼Œçœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹pptï¼Œä¸çœ‹ä¹Ÿæ²¡é—®é¢˜

6.Grand-canonical-cooperativity

6.1 Gibbs-Ensemble

finding a given state of the system(charaterized by an energy \(E_A\) and nuber of particles \(N_A\) is proportional to the numberof states available to the reservoir \(R\)) when the system is in thisstate

\[p_A = rac{Z}{e^{- eta(E_A-\muN_A)}}\] \[Z=\sum_ie^{- eta (E_i-\muN_i)}\]

çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorialï¼Œæ€ä¹ˆç”¨å…¬å¼

6.2 Cooperativity

ä½¿ç”¨ä¸ŠèŠ‚å…¬å¼ï¼Œçœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorialï¼Œæ€ä¹ˆç”¨å…¬å¼

7.Aminoacids-pKa-ATP-Phosphorylation

7.1 Aminoacids-pKa

Proteins, chirality, diversity, peptide bond formation, basic proteinstructure, from primary to quaternary structure, disease \(K_W=[OH^-][H_3O^+],pH\) \(pK_a=pH-\lg rac{[A^-]}{[AH]}\) å¾—ï¼š\( rac{[A^-]}{AH}=\dots\) \[p(A^-)= rac{1}{1+10^(pK_a-pH)}\]

\[p(HA)= rac{1}{1+10^(pH-pK_a)}\]

7.2 ATP

çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorial ATPæ€ä¹ˆç®—

7.3 Phosphorylation

çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorial ATPæ€ä¹ˆç®—

8. Diffusion

8.1 Mean Variance SEM

mean: \(\overline{x}= rac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}x_i=\sum_ip_ix_i=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}xp(x)dx\)\(\sigma:\) ä¸‰ç§å½¢å¼

æ¨ä¸€ä¸‹pptæ¦‚ç‡å…¬å¼ï¼Ÿ

8.2 Diffusion

Divergence theorem: \(\int_V abla \cdot\mathbf EdV =\oiiint \mathbf E\cdot d\mathbf A\) Continuityequation: \( abla\cdot\mathbf j(\mathbfr,t)=- rac{\partial ho(\mathbf r,t)}{\partial t}\) Flux: \(\mathbf j \equiv rac{Substance}{Area imesTime} = ho \mathbf v\) Fick's First Law: \[j = -D rac{d ho}{dx},\enspace \mathbfj=-D abla ho\]

Fick's Second Law: \[ rac{\partial ho}{\partialt}=D abla^2 ho\] Solution: \[ ho(x,t)= rac{ ho_0}{\sqrt{4\piDt}}e^{- rac{(x-x_0)^2}{4Dt}}\]

\[ ho(\mathbfr,t)= rac{ ho_0}{\sqrt{4\pi Dt}}e^{- rac{(\mathbf r-\mathbfr_0)^2}{4Dt}}\] mean: \(\overline{x}(t)=0\) variance: \(\sigma_x^2=2Dt\)

Brownain motionmicroscopic model: Random walk

\(\overline{X}=0\) But what countsis not the mean position, but the spread \(\sigma_x^2=N(\overline{x^2}-\overline{x}^2)=N\overline{x^2}=Nl^2=N\overline{v}l au=\overline{v}lt\)åˆï¼š\(\sigma _x^2(t)=2Dt\) \(D= rac{1}{2}\overline{v}l\) Differentequations for different situations are in ppt

\[x = \sigma_x =\sqrt{2D}\sqrt{t}\]

Diffusion with externalforces

\(v_D=\mu F= rac{1}{\gamma}mg\)Down-flux: \(j_1=\mu mg ho\) Up-flux:\(j_2=-D rac{d ho}{dh}\) \(j_1=j_2\) \[ ho(h)= ho_0e^(- rac{\mu mg}{D}h)\]

Compared to Boltzman distribution: \[ ho(h)= ho_0e^{- eta mgh},\enspaceE=mgh\]

Einstein Relation: \[D=\mu kT\]

Special case for Stoke's Law

Frictional force (drag force) exerted on spherical objects with verysmall Reynolds numbers (e.g., very small particles)in a continuousviscous fluid Stoke's Law: \[F=6\pi R\etav,\enspace \mu= rac{v}{F}\]

\[D = rac{kT}{6\pi R\eta}\]

Flux with external force: \(\mathbf{j}=-D abla ho +\mu F ho\)Diffusion equation with external force: \( rac{\partial ho}{\partial T}=D abla^2 ho-\muF abla ho\)

9. Electro

9.1 Poission-Boltzmann

Electronics for SaltySolutions

Magnetic fields play (almost) no role \[ abla\cdot\mathbf{E}(\mathbf{r})= rac{ ho(\mathbf{r})}{\varepsilon_0}\]Poisson's equation: \( abla^2\Phi(\mathbf{r})=- rac{ ho(\mathbf{r})}{\varepsilon_0}\)Laplace's equation: \( abla^2\Phi(\mathbf{r})=0\)

\(p_{Ion}(\mathbf{r})\propto e^{- etaE(\mathbf{r})}, \enspace E(\mathbf{r})=q\Phi(\mathbf{r})\)Charge density of the ion cloud: \[ ho_i(\mathbf{r})=q_in_i^{\infty}e^{- etaq_i\Phi(\mathbf{r})}\]

total charge density: \[ ho_{Ions}(\mathbf{r})=\sum_iq_in_i^{\infty}e^{- etaq_i\Phi(\mathbf{r})}\]

Poisson-Boltzman equation \[ abla^2\Phi(\mathbf{r})=- rac{e}{\varepsilon}\sum_{i=1}^nz_ic_{i,\infty}e^{- etaz_ie\Phi(\mathbf{r})}- rac{ ho(\mathbf{r})}{\varepsilon}\]

çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹tutorial

9.2 Debye-Huckel theory

Bjerrum length

Balance the ekectrostatic interaction energy: \[ rac{e^2}{4\pi\varepsilon_0Dl_B}=k_BT\]

\[l_B= rac{e^2}{4\pi\varepsilon_0Dk_BT}\]

Debye-Huckel theory

Debye-Huckle equation: \[ abla^2\Phi(\mathbf{r})= rac{e^2 eta}{\varepsilon}(\sum_iz_i^2n_i^{\infty})\Phi(\mathbf{r})\]

Debye length \[\lambda_D=( rac{\varepsilonk_BT}{e^2\sum_iz_i^2n_i^{\infty}})^{ rac{1}{2}}\]

Ionic strength \[I\equiv rac{1}{2}\sum_iz_i^2n_i^{\infty}\]

\[ abla^2\Phi(\mathbf{r})= rac{1}{\lambda_D^2}\Phi(\mathbf{r})\]

entry.title: QFTå’ŒQMçš„åŒºåˆ«
entry.content:
Differences between QFT andQM

1. Theoretical Framework and Scope -QM - Scopeï¼šPrimarily used to studythe behavior of microscopic particles such as electrons, protons, andatoms. - Objects of Descriptionï¼šIndividual particles'motion, energy, wave functions, etc. - FundamentalPrinciplesï¼šBased on SchrÃ¶dinger's equation, the probabilisticinterpretation of the wave function, and the uncertainty principle. -QFT - Scopeï¼š Used to describeinteractions between particles, especially in high-energy physics,addressing fundamental particles and forces. - Objects ofDescriptionï¼šThe relationship between fields and particles,where particles are seen as excitations of the underlying fields. -Fundamental PrinciplesBased on the quantization offields, covering electromagnetic fields, strong interactions, weakinteractions, etc.

2. Mathematical Tools and Methods -QM - Uses wave functions (or state vectors) to describeparticle states. - Employs SchrÃ¶dinger's equation or Heisenberg's matrixmechanics to describe the evolution of particles. - QFT- Utilizes field operators(\(\Psi(\boldsymbol{r})\)) to describe thequantum states of fields. - Applies Lagrangians, Hamiltonians, and pathintegrals to describe the evolution and interactions of fields.

3. Concept of Particles and Fields -QM - Particles are described by the probability densityof wave functions, exhibiting wave-particle duality. - Focuses on themotion, energy states, and evolution of particles' wave functions. -QFT - Particles are described as excitations of quantumfields, e.g., the electron field's quantum excitations are electrons. -Emphasizes the quantization of fields, where different types of fieldscorrespond to different particles.

4. Relativity - QM - Generallydeals with non-relativistic cases, where particles' velocities are muchless than the speed of light. - Relativistic quantum mechanics (like theDirac equation) is an extension but does not fully encompassrelativistic effects. - QFT - Fully compatible withrelativity, handling relativistic particles and interactions at highenergies. - For example, Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) describeselectromagnetic interactions within a relativistic quantum fieldframework.

5. Application Areas - QM - Mainlyapplied in atomic physics, molecular physics, condensed matter physics,quantum information, etc. - Describes the electronic structure andenergy levels within atoms, molecules, and solids. -QFT - Primarily applied in high-energy physics,particle physics, and cosmology. - Describes the fundamental particlesand forces, such as the electromagnetic force, strong force, and weakforce.

entry.content:

é‡è¯»æ–‡çŒ®ï¼šLow-RankCombinatorial Optimization and Statistical Learning by Spatial PhotonicIsing Machine

Introduction

Spational photonic Ising machine(SPIM)å¯ä½¿ç”¨ç©ºé—´å…‰è°ƒåˆ¶è§£å†³å¤§è§„æ¨¡çš„Isingproblemï¼Œå¿«é€Ÿè®¡ç®—å“ˆå¯†é¡¿é‡ã€‚æœ€åˆçš„SPIMåªèƒ½è§£å†³ç§©ä¸º1çš„ç›¸äº’ä½œç”¨çŸ©é˜µï¼Œåæ¥è§£å†³äº†è¿™ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼Œä½†å¯æ‰©å±•æ€§ä¸‹é™ã€‚ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯å¯æ‰©å±•æ€§ï¼Ÿï¼ è¿™é‡Œä»‹ç»äº†ä¸€ä¸ªmulticomponent computing model forSPIMæ¥å…‹æœä¸Šé¢çš„é™åˆ¶ï¼Œä¸”é€‚ç”¨é«˜ç§©çŸ©é˜µï¼Œä¸æ”¹å˜å…‰å­¦å®ç°ã€‚ ####ç›¸äº’ä½œç”¨çŸ©é˜µçš„æ„é€  å°†æ‰€æœ‰spinæ’æˆä¸€åˆ—ï¼Œ\(J_{i,j}\) æ˜¯ç¬¬\(i\) ä¸ªå’Œç¬¬\(j\) ä¸ªä¹‹é—´çš„ç›¸äº’ä½œç”¨ï¼Œ ####é‚£æˆ‘ä»¬åšçš„æ¨¡å‹çš„ç›¸äº’ä½œç”¨çŸ©é˜µçš„ç§©æ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æ›´å¤§ï¼Ÿå¯ä¼¸ç¼©æ€§æ€ä¹ˆæ ·å‘¢ï¼Ÿè¯æ˜äº†ï¼šå…·æœ‰æ»¡ç§©çš„ç›¸äº’ä½œç”¨çš„æ¨¡å‹å’Œæ™®é€šç»å°”å…¹æ›¼æœºè¡¨è¾¾èƒ½åŠ›ç›¸å½“ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯åœ¨é€šå¸¸çš„ä½ç§©å»ºæ¨¡çš„å‡è®¾ä¸­ï¼Œä½ç§©ç›¸äº’ä½œç”¨å°±è¶³å¤Ÿäº†ã€‚#### ä½†æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬çš„åŸºæœ¬ä¸Šæ˜¯æ»¡ç§©çš„ï¼Œè€Œä¸”æ²¡æœ‰å› æ­¤é™ä½é€Ÿåº¦ å¥½åƒæ˜¯\(N-1\)æ³¨æ„åˆ°æ–°å¯¼å‡ºçš„å­¦ä¹ è§„åˆ™è‡ªç„¶åœ°å¯¹å›¾åƒè¿›è¡Œä½ç§©å­¦ä¹ ï¼Œç„¶è€Œæ²¡æœ‰æ˜ç¡®åœ°æ–½åŠ ä½ç§©çº¦æŸã€‚What's the meaning of "low-rank learning" and "low-rank constraints"?
